item.title: Astro Bot: Winter Wonder Walkthrough (All Bots, Outfits, and Dual Speeder Skins)
item.description:
Winter Wonder is the sixth free DLC stage for Team Asobi's Astro Bot . Unlike the previous five, this one focuses more on exploration, with players needing to use almost all of the game's power-ups and abilities to find 15 Christmas presents. Each gift contains a different collectible, with seven Cameo Bots, four outfits, and four Dual Speeder skins on offer.

For the most part, Astro Bot players can open the presents up in whatever order they like, although the one containing the final Cameo Bot will only show up once players have found and opened the other 14. That said, we'll be listing them in the order that we feel makes the most sense, as some Winter Wonder collectibles are best collected in a certain order.

To gain access to the Winder Wonder stage, players will need to crash into the Christmas hat-wearing planet that can be found floating around on the Galaxy Select screen .

Quick Links

  • Winter Wonder Outfit #1 (Festive Fellow)
  • Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #1 (Rayman)
  • Winter Wonder Outfit #2 (Vengeful Spirit)
  • Winter Wonder Dual Speeder Skin #1 (Polygon Polychroma)
  • Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #6 (Miles Morales)
  • Winter Wonder Dual Speeder Skin #2 (Urban Dash)
  • Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #2 (Gex)
  • Winter Wonder Dual Speeder Skin #3 (Jolly Holly)
  • Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #3 (Tomba)
  • Winter Wonder Dual Speeder Skin #4 (Retro Royale)
  • Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #4 (Worm)
  • Winter Wonder Outfit #3 (Antler Adventurer)
  • Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #5 (Croc)
  • Winter Wonder Outfit #4 (Archstone Explorer)
  • Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #7 (Spider-Man)

Winter Wonder Outfit #1 (Festive Fellow)

Players will find the gift containing the Festive Fellow outfit near the very beginning of the stage and will unlock the Astro-ho-ho! Trophy upon obtaining it. The blue sign to the right of the present keeps track of how many gifts players have opened so far, which can be very useful if they ever lose track of their current total.

Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #1 (Rayman)

If players head to the blue balloons with the stopwatch on them they'll find a chest containing the stopwatch power-up from the Slo-Mo Casino stage. They can use this to ride the floating platforms to the ledge behind the turquoise-colored frog statue, where they'll find some birds flying around with a gift. By using the stopwatch again while the birds are close to the ledge, players will be able to grab and pull the wires coming out of the gift, causing it to fall and land beside them. Inside, they'll find a Cameo Bot based on the titular character from Ubisoft's Rayman games.

Winter Wonder Outfit #2 (Vengeful Spirit)

If players continue on from the Rayman Cameo Bot, they'll soon come to some brown balloons with monkeys on them. Buried beneath the snow here is a circular platform that they'll need to hover around the circumference of. Doing so will cause the platform to light up, at which point a chest containing the monkey power-up from the Go-Go Archipelago! stage will appear. After grabbing it, players should drop off the ledge to their left and look for two blue flowers on the nearby wall. Spin punching them will open up the wall that they're attached to, behind which players will find a gift containing the Vengeful Spirit Outfit, which is based on Jin Sakai from Ghost of Tsushima .

Winter Wonder Dual Speeder Skin #1 (Polygon Polychroma)

Back outside, players should climb back up to where they got the monkey power-up and then use the bananas to get up and over to the other side of the windmill. Here, they'll need to press L2 and R2 to slam the circular disc on the ground, which will dislodge some nearby snow and allow them to open the gift containing the Polygon Polychroma Dual Speeder skin.

Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #6 (Miles Morales)

After players get the Polygon Polychroma Dual Speeder skin, a swing bar will pop out of the ground, allowing them to get over to a platform with an igloo on it. If they punch the snowman inside the igloo, they'll see a blue X on the ground, and spin punching while standing on top of this will take them down to a secret area with a chest containing the puffer fish power-up first seen in the Sky Garden stage. Using this with the metal squid back up at the surface will take them to some floating platforms by the giant Christmas tree, at the top of which is a gift containing a Miles Morales Cameo Bot. To open it, players will need to use the puffer fish power-up with the pipe coming out of the side.

After landing on the first floating platform by the Christmas tree, players should be able to see a squid balloon to their left. Grabbing this will allow them to get to the very top of the Christmas tree, which will unlock the You're a star! Trophy. Players can also find a photo spot here if they enjoy taking pictures in Astro Bot .

Winter Wonder Dual Speeder Skin #2 (Urban Dash)

Near the beginning of the stage is a UFO carrying around a gift. There are a few different ways that players can get this one, the simplest of which is to use the stopwatch power-up to freeze time while the UFO is near a slope and then jump up and punch it. Doing so will cause it to drop the gift, allowing players to claim the Urban Dash Dual Speeder skin inside.

Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #2 (Gex)

Not too far from where the UFO can be found flying are some dark green balloons, which mark the position of the elephant power-up chest. After acquiring it, players should look for the nearby orange cubes and get on top of them using the orange gel that the little mole-like creature is holding. They can then suck up the orange gel cubes to release the present, which contains a Cameo Bot based on Gex.

Winter Wonder Dual Speeder Skin #3 (Jolly Holly)

Slap bang in the center of the stage is a shallow pit full of sparkling Christmas tree baubles. Hidden inside this pit is a cable that players can pull on to reveal a Christmas present containing the Jolly Holly Dual Speeder skin.

Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #3 (Tomba)

Near the center of the stage are some light blue balloons with a penguin on them. If players head down the well beneath them, they'll be able to get the penguin power-up from the Bubbling Under stage, which they can then use to break through the nearby destructible wall. On the other side of it, they should jump out of the water and punch open the gold gift, which will reward them with a Cameo Bot based on Tomba from Whoopee Camp's Tomba! games.

Winter Wonder Dual Speeder Skin #4 (Retro Royale)

Over to the left of the stage are some light green balloons, which mark the position of the frog power-up first seen in the Az-Tech Trail stage. After collecting it, players should swing on the red beams and then punch the giant green blob enemy until it explodes, which will reveal a slingshot contraption. Punching both sides of this and then pulling back will fire players over to a new island, where they'll need to punch the black crate off the ledge to get a chest containing the sponge power-up. If they then use this to spray water on the circle of saplings, they'll gain access to a gift containing the Retro Royale Dual Speeder skin.

Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #4 (Worm)

After collecting the Retro Royale skin, players should use the blue spinning platform to head back up to where they came from, where they'll now find a chest containing the canon ball power-up from the Hieroglitch Pyramid stage. If they hop into the nearby volcano while in ball form, they'll be blasted over to a house, where they'll need to use the power-up and the black platforms to get onto the roof and down the chimney. Inside the house is a gift containing a Cameo Bot based on one of the worms from Team 17's Worms franchise.

Winter Wonder Outfit #3 (Antler Adventurer)

If players head toward the gold balloons in the center of the stage, they'll find another giant pile of sparkly Christmas tree baubles. Using Astro's jets here will break the glass beneath the decorations, allowing players to drop down and open the chest containing the mouse power-up from the Downsize Surprise stage. Shrinking down and heading through the nearby tunnel will take them to a new area with a ship in a bottle. After reverting to normal size to pull out the cork, players should shrink down once again and head inside the bottle to find a gift containing the Antler Adventurer outfit.

Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #5 (Croc)

Players will need to use a spinning platform to exit the mouse area, which will lead them to a chest containing the Chicken power-up from the Trapped in Time stage. After using it to escape from the pit, they'll then want to use it again to get on top of the nearby lighthouse, where they'll find a gift containing the fifth Winter Wonder Cameo Bot. This one is based on the titular character from the Croc games, which should bring a big smile to the faces of those who grew up in the PS1 era.

Winter Wonder Outfit #4 (Archstone Explorer)

Over to the right of the giant Christmas tree are some brown balloons with teddy bears on them. These mark the position of the cymbal power-up, which players get to use in the Final Encore stage. If players ring the cymbals while standing close to the four lightbulbs nearby, the bulbs will light up, and a green rail will appear out of nowhere. Players should ride this rail around the stage until they reach a hidden area in the side of one of the stage's outer walls, at which point they'll want to jump off and head inside. Here, they'll need to use Astro's jets to push down one of the floor tiles, which will cause another Christmas present to appear. This one contains the Archstone Explorer outfit, which is inspired by The Slayer of Demons character from Demons Souls .

Winter Wonder Cameo Bot #7 (Spider-Man)

After players have opened all of the gold presents, a cutscene will play and a platinum present will appear beneath the giant Christmas tree. Inside this one, players will find the last Winder Wonder Cameo Bot, which is based on Marvel's Spider-Man. Rescuing this Bot will also unlock the Unwrapped! Trophy, which is the last of the three Winder Wonder Trophies.

item.title: Indiana Jones and the Great Circles Mysterious Cut Location Explained
item.description:
Summary

  • MachineGames cut a location from Indiana Jones and the Great Circle to maintain pacing and stay true to the game's vision.
  • The withheld location cut could have been Petra, Jordan, given its historical significance and connection to the franchise.
  • The missing area doesn't detract from the game's completion, highlighting that sometimes sacrifices are necessary in game development.

MachineGames' Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is undoubtedly an expansive game, taking players to historical locations like the Vatican, Cairo, Sukhothai, Shanghai, and the Himalayas, and letting them run free in one of the most authentic Indiana Jones gaming experiences ever made. Each locale in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is intentionally designed to pique players' curiosity and make them want to discover its secrets, whether they're a casual adventurer or seasoned explorer. Unfortunately, with a game as ambitious in scope as Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , there will always be sacrifices to make before the development process is finished.

Every game, no matter how big or how small it may be, begins with plans that aren't always able to come to fruition for one reason or another. Sometimes, elements of a game may be cut due to budgetary restrictions, and other times, these cuts may happen simply to rein in the game's identity to prevent it from losing itself. Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is one of the latest games to come out on the other side of development with some scars, as it was recently revealed that an entire location was cut from the game, despite there being no evidence of what location it might have been.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle Had a Location Cut From the Game

One Indiana Jones and the Great Circle Location Was Cut to Maintain the Game's Pacing

In an exclusive interview with Dexerto, creative director Axel Torvenius was asked if any locations were cut from the game, to which he replied, "All the locations were locked in fairly early, but we cut one location, which I will not mention." While he wouldn't disclose the location that was cut, he did say that it was due to that location being out of scope with the developer's vision for the game, which he explains meant that cutting it would allow the team to achieve "maximum pacing from a visual and creative point of view."

By the time the credits roll in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , it certainly doesn't feel like anything is missing from the game. Overall, it feels complete, whole, and exactly what it is supposed to be. In light of that, the location that was cut from Indiana Jones and the Great Circle wasn't really missed, which is just a sign that MachineGames and Bethesda made the right choice. Nevertheless, just as the game itself piques one's curiosity to venture out into the wilderness in search of adventure, the thought that there might have been, at one time, another extravagant location to visit in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is a thought worth exploring.

There Are Plenty of Notable Sites Along the Great Circle the Cut Location Might Have Been

While MachineGames and Bethesda wouldn't disclose what location was cut from Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , it's possible to speculate on what that location might have been by doing a closer look at the actual theory of the Great Circle. As Indy so eloquently lays out for Gina Lombardi in the game, the real-life Great Circle theory suggests that numerous ancient sites around the globe are aligned along a single, continuous great circle, and while many skeptics believe it to be nothing more than a coincidence, it has nonetheless intrigued researchers and historians for quite some time.

Considering the real-life Great Circle theory, there are several other notable locations that aren't featured in the game and yet align with the Great Circle. These locations include:

  • Easter Island (Rapa Nui)
  • Nazca Lines, Peru
  • Ollantaytambo, Peru
  • Tassili n'Ajjer, Algeria
  • Petra, Jordan
  • Persepolis, Iran
  • Mohenjo-Daro, Pakistan
  • Khajuraho, India
  • Angkor Wat, Cambodia

There's no telling what location was ultimately cut from Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , nor whether it was indeed one of the aforementioned locations that aligns with the real-life Great Circle. That being said, Petra, Jordan stands out as a location that Indiana Jones would be inclined to visit, given its historical significance and previous association with the franchise. Also known as the "Rose City," Petra was the backdrop for the Holy Grail's temple in Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade , which means it could have killed two birds with one stone by being a bit of fan service and offering a brand-new location for players to explore. However, the world may never know which location was cut from the game, unless MachineGames and Bethesda decide to spill the beans someday.

item.title: Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp Complete - Shovelstrike Quarry Guide
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How to Enter Shovelstrike Quarry in Pocket Camp Complete
    • Camper Cards and Leaf Tokens
  • Minerals and Rewards in Shovelstrike Quarry
    • How Are Rewards Calculated?

Shovelstrike Quarry in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp Complete is one way you can farm Bells, crafting materials, or Sparkle Stones. Here, you can farm minerals which determine your reward amount. You can determine the type of reward you'll get by the floating image over the Shovelstrike Quarry map icon. To get into Shovelstrike Quarry in Pocket Camp Complete , you can either ask for help or you can pay the entrance fee in Leaf Tokens.

How to Enter Shovelstrike Quarry in Pocket Camp Complete

Camper Cards and Leaf Tokens

If you select the Shovelstrike Quarry icon, you're prompted to ask 3 people for help or pay 20 Leaf Tokens to enter the quarry. If you don't have any Camper Cards registered, then it will be quicker to pay the 20 Leaf Tokens fee. However, you should save Leaf Tokens for crafting as you unlock more animals in Pocket Camp Complete .

In Pocket Camp , you had to ask 5 friends to enter the quarry. With Pocket Camp Complete , the friends feature was replaced with the Camper Cards. You can register another player's Camper Card and in doing so, their character will appear at Whistle Pass . It's at Whistle Pass where you can ask for quarry help . As mentioned, you'll need 3 helpers to enter the quarry . All you need to do is approach the other villagers at Whistle Pass and ask for help.

Not every villager will lend you their aid. Your best bet is to speak with every villager at Whistle Pass until you meet the quarry requirements.

You can register 10 Camper Cards at Pocket Camp Complete 's official website. Save the images with the QR Codes to your camera roll, where you can then scan them in-game to add them to your Cards.

  1. Select the " Cards " option at the bottom of your screen in Pocket Camp Complete.
  2. Choose a "blank" Card and it'll open a new window called " Scan QR Code ".
  3. Select " Images " if you already saved the card to your camera roll and select the card to scan.
    1. If you have not saved the image, choose the Official Website option to take you directly to the Camper Cards page. You don't need to save both images; save the one with the QR Code.

Minerals and Rewards in Shovelstrike Quarry

How Are Rewards Calculated?

Depending on the icon over Shovelstrike Quarry , you rewards will vary. In Shovelstrike Quarry, you can break five rocks to farm minerals. At the end, Lloid will give you rewards based on the types of minerals you were able to mine.

Each mineral has its own Bell value, but the value can change depending on the reward icon . If there's a crafting material (ie: steel, essence), then nuggets and gems are set to their base values. If the reward icon is a bag of Bells or Sparkle Stones, then the Bell value is increased.

Mineral Type

Mineral Bell Value

Item Reward from Mineral

Crafting Materials (ex: Wood, Cotton, Paper)

Gold Nugget

3000 Bells

20 Material

Silver Nugget

1500 Bells

10 Material

Ruby

1000 Bells

3 Material

500 Bells

5 Material

Essence (ex: Cool Essence, Cute Essence)

3000 Bells

10 Essence

Silver Nugget

1500 Bells

5 Essence

1 Essence

Sapphire

500 Bells

2 Essence

Bells

30000 Bells

N/A

Silver Nugget

10000 Bells

N/A

Ruby

3000 Bells

N/A

3000 Bells

N/A

Sparkle Stones

Gold Nugget

10000 Bells

2 Sparkle Stones

Silver Nugget

5000 Bells

1 Sparkle Stone

Ruby

2000 Bells

N/A

Sapphire

2000 Bells

N/A

* Reissue Material

Gold Nugget

3000 Bells

5 Material

Silver Nugget

1500 Bells

2 Material

* Gyroidites

Gold Nugget

5000 Bells

10 Gyroidites

Silver Nugget

2000 Bells

6 Gyroidites

* If the icon above Shovelstrike Quarry is a Reissue Material or Gyroidite, then you won't find any Sapphire or Ruby. The only minerals will be the Gold Nugget and the Silver Nugget.

If the reward icon is an Essence , and all you manage to farm are Sapphires, then you'll receive a total of 2500 Bells and 10 Essence. If the reward icon is Sparkle Stones and you get 5 Sapphires, then you'll have 10000 Bells and no Sparkle Stones.

item.title: Resident Evil 9 May Need 'More Time to Cook'
item.description:
Summary

  • Resident Evil 9 may face delays due to ambitious development plans.
  • Delays in major game releases are common for polished products, so fans shouldn't worry about Resident Evil 9.
  • Fans speculated on protagonist and story details, but official reveals from Capcom are still pending.

Fans have voiced disappointment after a rumored Resident Evil 9 announcement at The Game Awards 2024 never came to fruition, and an insider is now suggesting that Capcom's next installment in the zombie action franchise has been hit with delays. The Resident Evil series has been enjoying a renaissance with its critically acclaimed remakes and newer releases, but it may be some time until players are finally able to get their hands on Resident Evil 9 .

Capcom dropped a number of exciting announcements at The Game Awards 2024, including a new Onimusha title and an upcoming sequel to Okami . However, many were expecting a long-awaited announcement for Resident Evil 9 , the next major installment in the iconic survival horror series, and one insider is now chiming in with the latest rumors about the status of the game.

Resident Evil leaker Dusk Golem has alleged that Resident Evil 9 was originally supposed to be announced "last summer" but got pushed back following "an internal development delay." According to what they have heard, Resident Evil 9 is "a really ambitious game" that "needs more time to cook" compared to the recent Resident Evil remakes. Dusk Golem compared the rumored delay to the development cycle of the Resident Evil 2 remake, which itself had been pushed back a full year due to major reworkings. They have estimated that Capcom will be "working out where to fit it in the next couple years," though this is purely speculation and should not be taken as a confirmation of the game's release window.

Resident Evil 9 Allegedly Hit with Delays

Players have been speculating for months now on the rumored protagonist and potential story of Resident Evil 9 , though there have yet to be any official reveals from Capcom. Considering the number of titles currently in development at the studio, it would not be surprising if a major release like Resident Evil 9 has been given more time in the production incubator. While leakers such as Dusk Golem have often proven correct on various rumors, they are susceptible to missing the mark, so fans will want to await an official announcement from Capcom before drawing any solid conclusions about the future of Resident Evil 9 .

A number of major AAA video game releases have been hit with delays, and some fans may be worried that a lack of an announcement for Resident Evil 9 could spell trouble. However, studios frequently push back game releases and reveals to allow their development teams more time to create a polished product and an enjoyable experience, so players should not be deterred by the current Resident Evil 9 rumors. Interested players will want to stay tuned for updates on official announcements about Resident Evil 9 and other Capcom titles.

item.title: Elden Ring: Nightreign Co-Op Has Unfortunate Restriction
item.description:
Summary

  • Elden Ring: Nightreign allows solo play or groups of three only, no duo option available.
  • The restriction is for game balancing reasons.
  • Elden Ring fans are likely going to be disappointed to learn this.

It's been confirmed that the upcoming Elden Ring: Nightreign co-op game can only be played solo or in a group of three, with duos not possible. Elden Ring: Nightreign was one of the most shocking announcements at The Game Awards 2024. A co-op centric spin-off of Elden Ring , Nightreign is set to launch at some point in 2025.

The Elden Ring: Nightreign reveal trailer showed off a lot of the game's enemies and new features, but was surprisingly light on details that properly explained exactly what the game would be about. Some more information has since come to light, revealing that Elden Ring: Nightreign is not a massive open world adventure like the base game. Instead, it's basically an Elden Ring roguelite, with eight playable characters, eight main bosses, and a three-day structure that encourages repeat runs.

Fan reaction to this revelation has been mixed, to say the least. And now Elden Ring fans have some more unfortunate news when it comes to Nightreign . In an interview with IGN, Elden Ring: Nightreign game director Junya Ishizaki confirmed an unfortunate restriction when it comes to the game's co-op. It was confirmed that Elden Ring: Nightreign co-op can only be played solo or in a group of three. There is no option for two people to play together as a duo in Elden Ring: Nightreign .

Elden Ring: Nightreign - How Many Players?

  • Elden Ring: Nightreign can be played solo or in a group of three.

IGN asked Ishizaki why three was the "magic number" for Elden Ring: Nightreign , with the director saying that it was "largely a game balancing decision, rather than a game design decision." Ishizaki said that three players was the "sweet spot" without the game feeling "too overwhelming or busy." It was also explained that Elden Ring: Nightreign boss and enemy health scale if one is playing solo, so why that same logic couldn't apply to duos is unclear. Regardless, this revelation is no doubt going to disappoint some Elden Ring fans, especially when it has yet to be clarified how matchmaking will work in the game.

Elden Ring: Nightreign wouldn't be the first game to have this frustrating restriction for co-op. As some may recall, The Legend of Zelda: Tri-Force Heroes only allowed for 3-player co-op or solo play. That decision proved unpopular with Zelda fans, just like this decision will likely prove unpopular with Elden Ring fans.

Still, FromSoftware has a proven track record, and it would be best to wait to play the game before jumping to conclusions. While Elden Ring: Nightreign is currently without a release date, we do know that a network test will take place at some point before launch. Registrations for the Elden Ring: Nightreign network test will open on January 10, and fans should stay tuned for more details.
